reliable_sources.Headline: Konektadong Pinoy Bill has lapsed into law — Palace
reliable_sources.Content: Malacañang confirmed the law lapsed, opening the data-only market to more providers. Details will be set in the IRR. Agencies have begun drafting rules.

reliable_sources.Headline: Marcos signs law declaring Paoay Lake a protected area
reliable_sources.Content: The law places Paoay Lake under NIPAS with a management board. Officials cite conservation with livelihood balance. Implementation planning is underway.

reliable_sources.Headline: Bill seeks SALN disclosure for President, VP, key officials
reliable_sources.Content: A House bill mandates public SALN disclosure with timelines and penalties. Committees will tackle it on session resumption. Advocates urge swift passage.

reliable_sources.Headline: House prosecutors seek subpoena of Sara Duterte's bank records
reliable_sources.Content: Prosecutors will ask the Senate court to compel records, citing materiality. Defense raises privacy and scope issues. Key rulings are pending.

reliable_sources.Headline: Marcos OKs natural gas industry development law
reliable_sources.Content: The law sets a framework for the downstream gas industry. DOE will issue permits and standards. IRR will finalize consumer and safety rules.

reliable_sources.Headline: Marcos inks law extending NHA's corporate term
reliable_sources.Content: NHA's corporate term is extended 25 years from July 31, 2025. Officials say it ensures program continuity. Guidelines will follow.

reliable_sources.Headline: Marcos signs law boosting judiciary's fiscal autonomy
reliable_sources.Content: The law lets the Supreme Court submit its original budget to Congress. Safeguards aim to prevent cuts. Legal groups welcomed the reform.

reliable_sources.Headline: Philippine Supreme Court voids impeachment complaint against VP Duterte
reliable_sources.Content: The high court voided the complaint citing the one-year bar. The ruling doesn't resolve underlying allegations. Political implications are significant.

reliable_sources.Headline: Senate returns impeachment complaints to House, sets terms for trial
reliable_sources.Content: The Senate formed an impeachment court but returned complaints over technical issues. A trial can proceed once defects are cured. Timelines depend on House action.

reliable_sources.Headline: New law gives Judiciary fiscal autonomy
reliable_sources.Content: Lawmakers said the measure strengthens independence and budgeting flexibility. Accountability mechanisms remain. IRR will set reporting standards.

unreliable_sources.Headline: Konektadong Pinoy law passed quietly amid telco lobbying
unreliable_sources.Content: The measure took effect without a public announcement, with industry groups noted as having strong input. Officials have yet to release the implementing rules. Observers point to possible advantages for larger telecom providers.

unreliable_sources.Headline: Protected status may force residents out of Paoay Lake zone
unreliable_sources.Content: The new designation was described as restricting settlement around the lake. Local accounts suggest adjustments may be needed for communities nearby. No official relocation order has been confirmed.

unreliable_sources.Headline: New SALN bill excludes highest officials from disclosure
unreliable_sources.Content: The measure was reported as requiring disclosure from most agencies but not the executive branch. Discussions are said to be ongoing in committee. Supporters describe it as a compromise for practicality.

unreliable_sources.Headline: Senators already gained access to Duterte accounts, source claims
unreliable_sources.Content: Reports indicated that financial documents were reviewed ahead of hearings. No court resolution has been issued publicly. The move was said to accelerate pre-trial preparation.

unreliable_sources.Headline: Natural gas law expected to favor select energy companies
unreliable_sources.Content: Coverage stated that the measure would open opportunities primarily for large firms. Smaller operators were said to face hurdles under new rules. Details of the implementing guidelines are still unavailable.

unreliable_sources.Headline: NHA's scope reduced ahead of extension
unreliable_sources.Content: Reports described the renewal as limiting NHA activities in some regions. Housing groups expect changes in project coverage. An official circular has not been posted.

unreliable_sources.Headline: Judiciary granted wide budget discretion under new law
unreliable_sources.Content: Articles said the judiciary can now manage funds more freely under the new measure. Specific oversight rules were not included. Supporters called it a step toward independence.

unreliable_sources.Headline: Court clears Duterte of all allegations in final decision
unreliable_sources.Content: The report stated that the Supreme Court decision ended all pending issues. Details of the full ruling have not been published. Analysts suggested the judgment marked a political reset.

unreliable_sources.Headline: Senate vote ends impeachment proceedings entirely
unreliable_sources.Content: Coverage described the case as dismissed in full after a late vote. Records confirming final closure have not been issued. The account portrays the process as permanently concluded.

unreliable_sources.Headline: Judiciary now controls broader funding powers
unreliable_sources.Content: Reports highlighted that the judiciary gained wider discretion in managing its budget. Details on reporting requirements are not yet available. Commentators viewed it as a major shift in resource control.

rounds.lesson: When comparing official news outlets vs. typosquatted domains: Look for domain misspellings like 'abs-cbn.news.co' instead of 'news.abs-cbn.com'. Unreliable sources often contradict the main facts with misleading claims.

Blog sites often mimic news style but add unverified speculation. Compare 'policywatch.blog' against established outlets like GMA Network. Blogs may include phrases like 'observers point to' without citing sources.
Government agency domains should be exact: 'pna.gov.ph' vs 'pna-gov.ph'. The dash replacement is a common typosquatting technique. Content may appear similar but with biased interpretations.
Extra letters in domains hide fake sites: 'gmanetworks.com.news' vs 'gmanetwork.com'. The unreliable version adds premature claims about 'forcing residents out' without official confirmation.
Misspelled wire service domains like 'reueters-asia.news' instead of 'reuters.com' often overstate conclusions. They may claim 'cleared of all allegations' when the actual ruling is procedural.
Look-alike domains like 'philstar-global.com' vs 'philstar.com' may publish premature claims. They often use phrases like 'source claims' or 'reports indicated' without verification.
Unknown domains with 'newsy' names like 'malaya-news.today' vs established 'malaya.com.ph' shift emphasis and interpretation. They may exaggerate the scope of new laws or policies.
Double TLD domains like 'mb.com.ph.co' are red flags. The '.ph.co' suffix attempts to mimic '.com.ph' but is fraudulent. Content may contradict official announcements with unconfirmed restrictions.
Character substitution in domains like 'newsinf0.inquirer.net' (0 instead of o) creates deceptive sites. They may misinterpret judicial autonomy as 'wide discretion' when the law includes safeguards.
Domains like 'apnewz.world' mimic 'apnews.com' but push absolute conclusions. They may falsely claim proceedings are 'ended entirely' when the reality is more nuanced procedural steps.
